text: Noon sunlight streamed through the cracks in the clouds, falling over the inn’s signboard. Dust drifted lazily in the golden light.
The snow outside had melted in patches, leaving the cobblestones damp. The air was filled with the scent of bread and stew.
I was tossing the broken wood left from the morning’s chaos into the fire pit behind the inn. The flames crackled, heat rising into the cold air.
The rare calm of the day almost made me forget last night’s wind and noise.
But I didn’t expect her to return.
The doorbell chimed softly.

Alicia stepped inside, the frost on her armor still unthawed. Behind her was a young girl with chestnut hair tied in a short braid. Her bright eyes were full of curiosity, and in her arms she carried a basket of colorful bottles — like tiny drops of light trapped in glass.
“Shopkeeper, we brought you a few things. Healing potions and antidotes. I heard you often get drunkards hurting themselves around here.”
I blinked, still processing her words, while the young girl had already wandered to the counter, wide-eyed, taking everything in.
“Master, this place is so quiet! And so warm!”
“It doesn’t feel like an inn. It feels like a home.”
“Lucia, mind your tongue.”
“It’s fine. She’s right, though. This place is a bit too quiet.”
I put down the cloth in my hand and glanced toward the street outside the window.
“You used to hear the bells of caravans passing every day. Now you can go an entire day without seeing a soul.”
“They say beasts have appeared again in the northern forest.” I paused. “Several patrols vanished. Even the church won’t go near it.”
“Real monsters? I thought that was just a rumor!”
“Rumors often have roots. When we passed near there, I could feel the air wasn’t right… there was a smell—like rust.”
“You noticed that too?”
“Yes. The wind carried a scent of rust… or perhaps blood.”
“I thought it smelled kind of nice.”
“That only means you’re still a child.”
Watching the two of them, I felt a strange sense of peace—like their laughter was something precious in a world that had forgotten warmth.
“I made this one myself! It won’t make you drunk or dizzy—but it tastes really good! Wanna try, big brother?”
Lucia fumbled out a tiny bottle, popping the cork so hard it almost flew off. A sweet aroma filled the air instantly.
“Smell it! I mixed it with honey and strawberries!” she said excitedly, holding the bottle up to my face.
The scent hit me, and I coughed lightly before smiling. “Smells pretty good, actually.”
Alicia sighed softly beside her. “If you don’t want to sleep under your counter for three days, don’t drink it.”
“That was an accident!” Lucia puffed up her cheeks in protest, eyes wide with innocence.
“Her last experiment put her to sleep for three days straight.”
“It was an experiment error!”
Their banter was like a breeze through the room, sweeping away the gloom I’d carried all morning.
I suddenly realized—the air itself felt lighter since she walked in, as if the frozen river of my world had just started to thaw.

options.text: Option A: Ask Alicia if she wants to book a room for Lucia
Option B: Joke, 'Are you two sharing a room?'
